metadata.title: Supporting Information for Evaluation and prediction of the COVID-19 variations at different input population and quarantine strategies, a case study in Guangdong province, China

affiliation.laboratory: State Key Laboratory of desert and Oasis Ecology

body_text.text: It should be noted that Sce 0 is our baseline obtained in the first aspect. The results of Sce 1-Sce 8 are used to compared with the baseline results which is demonstrated the impacts of different input population on the disease variations.

For aspect 2, the effects of the quarantine rates variations are explored, the changed rates of q 1 * and q 2 * are 0, 0.5 and 1 which indicates the quarantine strategies are becoming weakened quantitatively in the susceptible individuals and exposed individuals. We also have nine scenarios as Scenario 1 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , 0q 2 * ); Scenario 2 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , 0.5q 2 * ); Scenario 3 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , q 2 * ); Scenario 4 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0.5q 1 * , 0q 2 * ); Scenario 5 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0.5q 1 * , 0.5q 2 * );

Because the quarantine rate q 1 must smaller than q 2 in our quarantine strategies, and the baseline in the above scenarios should be ignored, we have the adjusted scenarios as Scenario 1 (Sce1): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , 0q 2 * ); Scenario 2 (Sce2): (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , 0.5q 2 * );

For the last aspect (i.e. aspect 3), the effects of both the input population and the quarantine rates variations are discussed. The changed rates of p 2 * and A * are 1.5 and 2, and the changed rates of q 1 * and q 2 * are 0 and 0.5. The scenarios (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0.5q 1 * , 0) cannot exist which is not agreement with our quarantine strategies. We have twelve scenarios as follows:

We further assume that these aspects are applied at different time points from the first day Jan 27, 2020 which is simulated in our model. The time span is 10 days, noted as t 1 = 10, t 2 = 20, t 3 = 28 and t 4 = 38 which are corresponding to Feb 6, 2020, Feb 16, 2020, Feb 24, 2020 and Mar 5, 2020. Because the Guangdong province has been adjusted the emergency response level of epidemic prevention and control from the first level response to the second level at Feb 24, 2020 (http://www.gd.gov.cn/), the third time point is defined as t 3 = 28, and the last time point is t 3 = 38. To be more close to the actual situation, the quarantine of the susceptible individuals will be removed (i.e.q 1 = 0) when the population migration reaches a balance level between the input population and output population.

The accuracy of our model is evaluated by the cumulative confirmed cases, confirmed cases and recovered cases at the last four days (i.e. Feb 21, Feb 22, Feb, 23 and Feb 24). Then, with the baseline parameters, the COVID-19 variations are predicted till with the same input and output population. The largest number of the cumulative confirmed cases, daily new confirmed cases, confirmed cases will be obtained as well as the corresponding days. The recovered cases will also be displayed.
Assuming the observed COVID-19 cases are A = (a 1 , a 2 , · · ·, a n ) and the simulated data of SEIRQ model is B = (b 1 , b 2 , · · ·, b n ), we have
whereā andb are the mean values of A and B, N AE is the ratio between AE andā, and

FIGREF0.text: The bigger value of R * 2 and the smaller values of AE, RE, M AP E and DISO mean the higher accuracy by the model simulation (Hu et al., 2016, 2019). Simulation and prediction of the COVID-19 in Guangdong province. (A) cumulative confirmed cases; (B) daily new confirmed cases and (C) difference of increased confirmed cases. The initial values and parameters are S(0) = 113346174, E(0) = 31, I(0) = 19, R(0) = 4, S q (0) = 113460, E q (0) = 128, I q (0) = 184, A = 86926, B = 21356, p 1 = 0.9999927, p 2 = 0.0000073, p 3 = 0, q 1 = 0.28, q 2 = 0.76, q 3 = 0.89, α = 0.00375, β = 2.45 × 10 −8 , ν = 0.183, σ = 0.63, γ(t) = 0.008 + 0.19/(1 + e 5.0126−0.1846t ).

FIGREF1.text: Aspect 1, effects of the input population at different scenarios. t 1 = 10, t 1 = 20, t 1 = 20 and t 1 = 38 are four different time points. DDE: Days of Disease Extinction; MVCCC: Maximum Values of Cumulative Confirmed Cases; PVCCC: Peak Value of Confirmed Cases; DPVCCC: Days of PVCCC. STable 2: Aspect 2, effects of quarantine rates at different scenarios. t 1 = 10, t 1 = 20, t 1 = 20 and t 1 = 38 are four different time points. DDE: Days of Disease Extinction; MVCCC: Maximum Values of Cumulative Confirmed Cases; PVCCC: Peak Value of Confirmed Cases; DPVCCC: Days of PVCCC. STable 3: The scenarios of aspect 2 with (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0.01q 1 * , 0.01q 2 * ), (0q 1 * , 0.05q 2 * ) at t 1 = 10, and (q 1 , q 2 ) = (0q 1 * , 0q 2 * ) at t 1 = 11, and the other parameters as the baseline values. DDE: Days of Disease Extinction; MVCCC: Maximum Values of Cumulative Confirmed Cases; PVCCC: Peak Value of Confirmed Cases; DPVCCC: Days of PVCCC. STable 4: Aspect 3, effects of both input population and quarantine rates at different scenarios. t 1 = 10, t 1 = 20, t 1 = 20 and t 1 = 38 are four different time points. DDE: Days of Disease Extinction; MVCCC: Maximum Values of Cumulative Confirmed Cases; PVCCC: Peak Value of Confirmed Cases; DPVCCC: Days of PVCCC.
